abstract.p: Background: In Ohio, levy campaigns are a burdensome task for district administrators and stakeholders alike. To date, there is little research on the districts’ role in crafting school budget referenda campaigns. Purpose: This study asked three research questions: How did the macropolitical contexts shape stakeholders’ decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation? How did the micropolitical contexts shape stakeholder decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation? How did successful districts differ in political strategies from districts that were not successful? Research Design: Qualitative case studies. Data Collection: Twenty-three informants from five Ohio school districts with levies on the November 2008 ballot. Using a snowball sampling technique, initial informants (i.e., superintendent, treasurer) were asked to identify additional stakeholders who participated in the campaigns. Data Analysis: Coding was initially guided by multiple theoretical frameworks, including macro/micropolitics, Johnson’s 21 campaign strategies and Anderson’s framework of “authentic” participation. After coding, an iterative team memo-writing process was used. Findings: This study offers important insight into the complexities of the environments and strategies used in levy campaigns. Four macropolitical themes were identified—state campaign policies, state education finance policy, the high-profile nature of the Presidential election, and the state of the economy. Despite a small sample, districts varied greatly in strategies used and community involvement. Districts that heavily engaged community members and created a sense of urgency yielded greater success at the polls than “central office campaigns.” Adequate message training for campaign participants was also integral to success.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: November 4, 2008 will be remembered in history as the day that the United States elected the first African American President. Some will look back on that day as one of joy and optimism for the hope and change on which candidate Obama campaigned. Hope and change meant many things—a postracial society, health care reform, an end (or at least a reduction) of hostilities in Iraq and Afghanistan, and an end to the deep recession. Others will remember the day more tentatively, as one of an uncertain future. Still others will remember the day as one of great disappointment at the loss of the McCain–Palin ticket. Although it is too early to know what the legacy of the Obama administration will be, the day is undoubtedly a first in the nation’s history.

What is less memorable is that on that same historic day, voters all across Ohio—a state identified as a key “battleground” state (Caswell, 2009)—cast votes on a total of 236 levies statewide, seeking additional or status quo funding for schools. President Obama’s background as a community organizer on Chicago’s Southside—a background that undoubtedly contributed to his successful presidential bid—is well-documented (Allen, 2008; Guinier, 2008; Mack & Chen, 2004; Moberg, 2007). Like Obama in Chicago and his presidential campaign workers, community organizers in these districts planned and implemented campaign strategies in pursuit of voter approval with varying levels of engagement and success toward their goal—at least 51% of constituents voting yes.

The troubles and litigation surrounding Ohio’s school finance program are well-documented (Alexander & Alexander, 2009; Johnson & Ingle, 2009; Hunter, 2000; Maxwell & Sweetland, 2008; McKinley & Phillis, 2008; Murphy, 1983). As with many U.S. states, Ohio funds public education through a combination of local property taxes and state aid. What makes Ohio unique is the frequency in which voters are asked to decide school budget referenda. Fleeter (2007) states that “Ohio relies on voter approval of tax levies to support public education to a greater extent than any other state in the nation” (p. 1). The omnipresent school levy on Ohio ballots is the result of a 1976 constitutional amendment, originally known as House Bill 920, that prohibits property taxes from increasing as property values rise; thus districts are forced to continually return to the ballot just to keep up with inflationary costs. Maxwell and Sweetland (2008) have noted,
Ohio’s schools are sometimes faced with the dilemma of explaining that the schools are receiving no additional funds from voted in taxes. Under an accountability model, this leaves school officials with an ‘uphill’ task in convincing voters that additional revenues are necessary. (§4.10)

In the state of Ohio, school funding is complicated by property tax policies that neutralize automatic increases in local revenue (i.e., real estate property reduction factor, tax abatement, and the reduction of the personal tangible property tax assessment rates). When real estate property values increase due to reappraisal or the triennial update cycle, tax rates are reduced such that the districts continue to collect the same amount of revenue from voted levies applied to the same property (Maxwell & Sweetland, 2008).

In Ohio, levy campaigns are an ongoing burdensome task, depleting energy and resources that could (potentially) be better spent toward improving academic performance (Ingle, Petroff, & Johnson, 2011). As a point of reference, operating levies in Ohio typically range from 2 to 10 mills. From February 1994 to November 2006, Ohio voters only approved 40.4% of all new property and income tax levies while renewal and replacement levies were approved by voters at a rate of 83.3% (Fleeter, 2007). In the November 2008 campaign period, the passage rate was lower for new operating levies, with only 22.2% of them being approved by voters. As will be shown, Ohio law limits the role that districts and their personnel can play in campaigns. As a result, each district finances their campaigns through private donations. School and district personnel can play active roles in the campaigns, but must limit their activities to before and after school hours. Otherwise, they risk being accused of violating state law. District administrators, school boards, and other key stakeholders in Ohio communities must weigh their options and pursue courses of action to ensure adequate, or at the least, status quo funding. In doing so, many decisions must be made. First, these stakeholders must select from an array of levy options. In November 2008, Ohio districts put forth 42 variations and combinations of levies on the ballot. With four possible times in which levies can be placed on the ballot (February, May, August, November), key stakeholders must also decide when to place the levy (or levies) on the ballot. Once these decisions are made, the campaign strategizing to face the political conditions within the district begins.

Part of a larger project that sought to estimate the costs of five new operating levies (Ingle, Petroff, & Johnson, 2011), this study examined the macro/micropolitical environments, the campaign strategies used in their efforts to gain voter approval, and the stakeholders involved in campaigning. Using interviews with 23 key stakeholders (e.g., superintendent, treasurer, campaign committee chair, volunteers) across five districts, this study sought answers to the following questions:

list-item.p: How did the macropolitical contexts shape stakeholders’ decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation?
How did the micropolitical contexts shape stakeholder decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation?
How did successful districts differ in political strategies from districts that were not successful?

sec.p: Although not generalizable beyond the five sampled districts in the time period leading up to the November 2008 election, our study offers important insight into the complexities of their macro/micropolitical environments and the strategies used to win support for school levies. Indeed, it has been noted that the purpose of a case study is “not to represent the world, but to represent the case” (Stake, 2005, p. 460).

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: We now will discuss the relevant research literature to frame our study of the macropolitical, micropolitical, and strategic contexts of five Ohio school districts. First, we examine the extant literature on factors associated with referenda outcomes, summarizing primary variables of interest and their relationships. We then briefly discuss the research on community engagement and the strategies schools, districts, and stakeholders undertake in its pursuit. Finally, we briefly summarize the research using a micro- and macropolitical lens to examine school and district environments.

Research on school budget referenda has examined the relationship between various factors and referenda outcomes, such as subpopulations’ voting behaviors (e.g., Bali, 2008; Ehrenberg, Ehrenberg, Smith, & Zhang, 2004; Gradstein & Kaganovich, 2004; Ladd & Murray, 2001). Notably, research has focused on the percentage of elderly voters within districts and its impact on school budget referenda. These studies have produced mixed results, having some studies (e.g., Ladd & Murray, 2001; Poterba, 1997) suggesting that an increase in the percentage of elderly voters was not associated with a decrease in educational spending per student except when the elderly and school-age populations came from different racial groups. Others (e.g., Gradstein & Kaganovich, 2004) indicate that retirees prefer a decrease in the amount of spending on education, rationalizing that they will not live to see the benefits or that they have long borne the tax burden across their many years.

Research has also examined the relationship of district characteristics (e.g., Authors, 2009; Berkman & Plutzer, 2006; Bowers & Lee, 2011; Bowers, Metzger, & Militello, 2010a, 2010b; Lentz, 1999; Sanders & Lee, 2009) to school budget referenda outcomes. For example, Lentz (1999) examined referenda from Illinois school districts in the period 1981-1989. Using a school district jurisdictional typology consisting of six categories of school districts based on land use, Lentz found that homogeneous districts (small rural and residential suburbs) had significantly higher passage rates than heterogeneous districts. For all jurisdictional types, land use homogeneity, prior willingness to pay higher taxes for schools and capacity to pay were the most important predictors of referenda outcomes. More recently, Bowers et al. (2010a, 2010b) found that rural districts were at a greater disadvantage in passing bond elections than urban/suburban districts. School districts in small municipalities fared worst of all. Bowers et al. (2010a, 2010b) found rural and small municipality school districts less likely to pass school construction bonds in Michigan. However, Bowers and Lee (2011) did not produce comparable results in their Texas school construction bonds study and suggest that district locale and its impact on outcomes may be state/context specific.

In another recent study examining voting results for school district budgets in the state of New York from 2003 to 2010, Silverman (2011) reported that larger districts were more likely to vote for local property tax increases, but districts with larger minority populations, larger overall growth in school budgets, and higher voter turnout were associated with a decrease in the likelihood of passage. Shober (2011) sought to answer whether school choice options (i.e., charter schools and magnet schools) increase the likelihood of school budget referenda success. He found that the number of charter schools was associated with an increase in the likelihood of passage, while the number of magnet schools was not. The percentages of college-educated residents and senior citizens were also significantly related to an increased likelihood of school referenda passage.

Research has also examined other factors, such as the amounts/millage requested, experience levels of school board members, and the number of times a referendum is attempted in relation to outcomes (Authors, 2009; Balsdon, Brunner, & Rueben, 2003; Bowers et al. 2010a, 2010b; Bowers & Lee, 2011; Ehrenberg et al., 2004). Nonstrategic district characteristics are conditions and contexts in which school budget referenda advocates (and opponents) must operate. These factors can be significant, but it comes down to voter behaviors behind the curtain. Bali (2008) notes that individuals’ decision making at the polls is motivated by ideological predispositions, self-interest, and racially based incentives. However, referenda advocates can pursue strategies that can increase the likelihood of a positive outcome. This leads us to our discussion of the importance of community engagement and strategies for increasing such involvement.

The community engagement research has examined why parents become involved in education, focusing largely on the relationships that develop between parents and teachers (e.g., Hoover-Dempsey & Sandler, 1997; Miretzky, 2004). Apple and Beane (1995) have argued that local decision making is held up as an ideal, but it remains largely in the realm of rhetoric. The highly hierarchical, bureaucratic structure of schools and educators’ self-perceptions of professionalism leads to resistance and devaluation of what is deemed as “unprofessional” parent/community input (Cibulka, 1996; Mediratta & Fruchter, 2003). Similarly, Furman and Starratt (2002) cite fear of a lack of control as to why the application of democracy in schools is minimal at best with parents, who are often relegated to visitor and support-at-home roles. When school councils were able to have an impact on classroom practices and decision making, competent parent chairpersons, supportive principals, and a past history of positive parent–teacher relationships were positive (albeit) weak predictors. Evidence suggests that stakeholder participation in educational reform efforts seldom goes beyond rhetoric or superficiality (Anderson, 1998; Beare, 1993; Hargreaves, 1994; Malen & Ogawa, 1988; Schutz, 2006; Smyth, 1993; Spillane & Thompson, 1997). As Schutz (2006) recently noted, “schools and school districts erect barriers with one hand while reaching out with another” (p. 726).

Researchers have identified strategies for increasing community engagement, largely focusing on urban settings (e.g., Glickman & Scally, 2008; Gold, Simon, Mundell, & Brown, 2004; Schutz, 2006) and among schools serving large percentages of minority populations (Arriaza, 2004). The development of social capital, community leadership, and input builds community capacity and can increase public accountability for improving schools in ways that benefit those who have most often been disadvantaged. The alternative is the unfortunate development of antagonistic relationships between communities and schools in which each side plays the blame game for problems within the school and/or district (e.g., Glickman & Scally, 2008; Gold, Simon, & Brown, 2002).

As to strategies affecting voters’ support for education issues, the literature identifies factors, such as understanding what voters will support, presenting a focused referendum, presenting a unified front from multiple stakeholders, targeting “yes” voters, communicating important information, and developing good relationships with the local media (Johnson, 2008; Boschee, 2003; Carter & Devries, 1967; Conrad, 2002; Davis & Tyson, 2003; Holt, 1984). However, these are prescriptive articles and case studies that suggest best practices and “what worked for us” in specific district contexts. For example, Carter and Devries (1967) espoused “ten commandments” for successful levy campaigns: know where you stand before attempting to convince the public, enlist the aid of citizens to champion your cause, stay in the background and function as a research source, ignore the opposition, build the campaign around an emotional appeal, use inexpensive brochures, do not threaten the public, do not count on newspaper support, concentrate on the “yes” voters, do not forget the public after the issue passes, and continue an aggressive public campaign.

Johnson (2008) examined 21 school levy strategies identified through a literature review associated with successful school levy campaigns in the context of a single Ohio case study district. However, most of the research consisted of unpublished dissertations and professional/trade journals. While the study confirmed the importance of these strategies, it also presented evidence of a two-step approach to planning levy campaigns that might help districts pass levies. This included a first campaign that successfully used the traditional strategy of a high profile, high voter turnout campaign and a second low-profile campaign designed to specifically target “Yes” voters and rally them to the polls. Both steps in the end were essential to the campaign’s final victory. The first campaign may best be described as a “shotgun approach” whereas the second campaign is akin to a “rifle shot with a silencer,” in that it is much more specific in who is targeted and seeks to target yes voters quietly in order not to provoke no voters. More recently, Silverman (2011) suggested that school districts should adopt participatory budget tools and involve community stakeholders in decision making in order to promote sustainable educational resources.

Community engagement experts (e.g., Anderson, 1998; Arriaza, 2004; Comer, 1993, 1998; Epstein, 2001; Schutz, 2006) have suggested that community members can be the greatest adversaries or allies to a district’s efforts. For the community to be the latter, school leaders must be open to community engagement and toward that end, gain an extensive knowledge of the communities in which they serve and provide meaningful ways in which stakeholders can be involved in the education of their youth. Notably, Anderson (1998) developed a framework that examines the micro- and macropolitical considerations influencing what he terms authentic participation. Anderson found that “authentic participation” is atypical. Limited and/or “inauthentic” forms of participation are dominant in schools—the consequences of which are the reinforcement of exclusionary power perceptions in school systems. Indeed, Anderson (1998) contends that discourse alone
has been used to promote a variety of—often contradictory—social policies and has been used as a cover term for institutional arrangements and management techniques that, while purporting to advance democracy and change, too often tend to support an inequitable status quo, (p. 587)
thus resulting in a decreased likelihood of true community-school engagement.

Research examining the micropolitics within schools suggests that the behaviors of stakeholders—including strategies and tactics—are strongly influenced by their varied interests (Ball, 1987; Blase, 1991, 1997; Hoyle, 1982). Although these disparate interests may foment struggles for power, influence, and control, they may also lend themselves to collaboration, negotiation, and coalition building (Blase, 1991). In the case of school budget referenda, the behaviors and participation of stakeholders can range widely. Behaviors and participation may be limited to ballot casting at the polls or heavily engaged as an active campaign volunteer. For participation to be the latter, the potential volunteer to some degree must be motivated and encouraged to participate. In one recent study (Johnson & Ingle, 2009), it was reported that only 66% of superintendent respondents indicated community stakeholders were involved in their districts’ levy campaigns. For districts that involved community members, the level of participation varied from extremely active “grassroots” volunteerism to community committees in which members served as ceremonial or figurehead roles only.

Iannaccone (1975) described the focus of micropolitics of schools as “the interaction and political ideologies of social systems of teachers, administrators, and pupils within school buildings” (Iannaccone, 1975 p. 43). The conceptual boundaries and distinctive features of micropolitics remain elusive and contested (Bjork & Lindle, 2001; Mawhinney, 1999; Malen & Cochran, 2008). There is debate as to whether district-level politics are in the macro- or micropolitical realm. However, macro- and micropolitics are grounded in similar concepts, such as power, formal/informal arenas, influence, control, conflict/cooperation, strategies, exchange, negotiation, interest groups, values, and ideologies (Ball, 1987; Blase & Blase, 2002; Marshall & Scribner, 1991; Wirt & Kirst, 2005). The extant research on district-level politics has been described as drawing “the intermittent attention of political scholars” (Bjork & Lindle, 2001, p. 77). While there has been interest in the districts’ role in implementing state/federal policies (e.g. Iatarola & Fruchte, 2004; Rorrer, Skrla, & Scheurich, 2008; Rutledge & Park, 2009), there is little research on the district’s role in school budget referenda campaigns, who and how district leaders involve community stakeholders and how macro- and micropolitical conditions shape campaign strategies and participation.

sec.title: Site Selection
sec.p: Our study examined five districts pursuing new operating levy campaigns that were on the November 2008 ballot in the state of Ohio (see Table 1). New operating levies were chosen, as research suggests that these levies have the highest failure rates among voters (Johnson & Ingle, 2009; Fleeter, 2007). Indeed, November 2008 campaign results saw only 22 of 99 new operating levies approved by voters in their districts. Selected were two rural districts (one passed its levy, one failed), two suburban districts (one passed, one failed), and one urban district (passed). The paired districts were purposively selected due to their similarities, including student populations served, district typology, and performance under Ohio’s school accountability system.1 With regard to the single urban school district, Ohio has 15 districts that are classified by the Ohio Department of Education (ODE) as “Major Urban School Districts with Very High Poverty.” Because of there being only one urban district with a failed new operating levy—and an inability to protect the identity of the district—only one urban district (passing its levy) was selected.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: District-level administrators, school-level administrators, teachers, and parent volunteers in the selected Ohio school districts were interviewed for the project. In total, 23 informants from the 5 sampled districts were interviewed. Preliminary informants were purposively selected based on their leadership roles within the district and/or campaign (i.e., district superintendent, school treasurer). Using a snowball sampling technique, initial informants were asked to identify additional stakeholders who participated in the campaigns and would serve as useful informants (e.g., community campaign chair, parent-, teacher-, and community volunteers). The semistructured interviews were approximately 1 to 2 hours in length and consisted of questions related to their role in the levy campaign, the costs associated with the campaign, and the extent to which the community was engaged (and how). Informants were asked to discuss levy campaign activities in terms of three stages: campaign planning, campaign implementation, and campaign debriefing. We define debriefing activities as those that involve analyzing the results and factors that contributed to the success or defeat of the levy campaign being studied. The interviews were completed between December 2008 and May 2009—within 6 months of the November 2008 election day. This was done to mitigate any loss of details due to the passage of time. Interviews were audio recorded and transcribed verbatim.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Transcripts were coded using NVivo7 and an iterative team memo-writing process (Miles & Huberman, 1994). Our coding of the transcripts was both deductively and inductively driven. With regards to the former, we were guided by multiple theoretical frameworks, including shared concepts within macro- and micropolitics, such as power, formal/informal arenas, influence, control, conflict/cooperation, strategies, exchange, negotiation, interest groups, values, and ideologies (Ball, 1987; Blase & Blase, 2002; Marshall & Scribner, 1991; Wirt & Kirst, 2005). As stated previously, the conceptual boundaries and distinctive features of micropolitics remain elusive and contested, particularly as to whether district-level politics are in the macro- or micropolitical realm. Within the context of this study, the micropolitical environment refers to the politics that takes place within the sampled districts, their schools, and the communities they serve. The macropolitical environment refers to the politics that takes place at the state (Ohio) and federal levels. We also used Johnson’s (2008) 21 political strategies2 employed in levy campaigns to categorize levy campaign strategies. Last, we drew on Anderson’s (1998) framework of “authentic” and “inauthentic” participation to inform our analysis of stakeholder involvement in the levy campaigns. In addition to these frameworks, we also developed codes drawing from our own iterative and inductive process.

After the data were coded, we used an iterative team memo-writing process in our analysis (Miles & Huberman, 1994). Memo writing is an analytical tool that allows qualitative researchers to abstract meaning from data through a process in which the researcher becomes immersed in the data and reflectively writes on emerging codes and themes, one’s own subjective experience, and the interplay of subjective influences on the collection and interpretation of data. It has been noted that memo writing is not restricted to the analytical phase of research. Memo writing also aids in the mapping of preliminary research activities (e.g., data collection) and facilitates communication among members of the research team (Birks, Chapman, & Francis, 2008). For this study, individual members of the research team independently analyzed the coded data and wrote memos in which we analyzed findings on individual school districts and research questions. As a group, we then met face-to-face to discuss the content of the memos. We discussed their content, the extent to which similar themes emerged, and determined whether further analysis was needed. Memos were written until we had achieved theoretical and empirical saturation (Denzin & Lincoln, 1998).

sec.title: Macropolitics
sec.p: We first turn our attention to the macropolitical conditions at the state and federal levels in which the informants reported as shaping the campaigns and participation. Our analysis suggests four major macropolitical themes—state campaign policies, state education finance policy, the high profile nature of the November 2008 ballot, and last, the economy of Ohio and the nation (see Table 2). With regard to the first of these, all school district employees interviewed for this study regardless of district were always quick to point out that their campaign activities were before or after the school day had ended. Per §9.03 of the Ohio Revised Code, political subdivisions can expend public funds to communicate information, but not to support or oppose the passage of a levy or bond issue. When asked directly how much time on the campaign was during school hours, the superintendent from District C replied, “I don’t want people to think this is happening during our normal business hours. The hours for levy went above beyond what it took to do our jobs.”

sec.p: With regard to state education finance policy, informants—specifically superintendents, treasurers, and school board members—discussed the nature of education finance in the state of Ohio. District-level leaders consistently discussed the uncertainty—not only of the economy, but also the future of education funding in Ohio. In 2006, Ted Strickland was elected Ohio’s 68th governor with the campaign promise of fixing the school-funding system in Ohio.3 By 2008, Governor Strickland was traversing the state, conducting a series of town hall meetings seeking input from constituents on how to do just that. One of the themes that emerged from these meetings was the overreliance on local property taxes for the support of local schools. The message emerging from the Governor’s meetings and speeches was that the solution was to reduce the reliance on local property taxes by increasing the state’s share of the school-funding formula (Office of the Governor, 2008, n.d.). This solution garnered the broad-based support of both taxpayers and educators. However, one of the unintended consequences was that it sent the message to local taxpayers that support of local tax levies may not be necessary since the state was perceived as taking care of the problem. One informant from District D simply referred to the Governor’s discussions as a “curveball that he threw.”

The superintendents, treasurers, and school board members interviewed as part of this study not only discussed the complexities of Ohio’s school-funding mechanism but also consistently discussed the inevitability of returning to the ballot that results from the state’s system. When asked if the passage of the November 2008 levy would result in being on the ballot less often, none suggested that they held much hope in being on the ballot less in the foreseeable future. District E’s Superintendent stated, “We are on the ballot a lot . . . There have been five campaigns in seven years and we have passed three of them.”

November elections have tended to be a popular time to place levies on the ballot. There are two reasons for this higher propensity—costs and timing. “Charge back” costs—board of elections fees charged to districts for placing a levy on the ballot—are less in November because there are more referenda on the ballots when there are national elections, especially in presidential elections. In addition, Ohio state law caps how much the county board of elections can charge during a presidential general election. As such, the costs of placing a levy on the ballot in November are typically lower than other times in the year. Furthermore, voter turnout is higher in U. S. presidential elections than in midterm elections where state races for governor top the ballot (e.g., Jennings & Zeigler, 1970: McAtee & Wolak, 2011). There is evidence that suggests greater intensity in battleground states (Hill & McKee, 2005), and Ohio has been identified as such a state (e.g., Caswell, 2009; Cheng & Riffe, 2008). According to Fleeter (2007), Ohio levies have historically had higher passage rates when placed on the May primary or November general election ballots in comparison with February and August Special Elections. Fleeter (2007) suggests that this is “a consequence of lower voter turnout in the special elections” (p. 17). While conventional wisdom suggests that Democrats (and education issues) benefit from high voter turnout, the political science research actually indicates mixed results (e.g., DeNardo, 1980; Holbrook & McClurg, 2005; Nagel & McNulty, 1996; Osborn, McClurg, & Knoll, 2010; Radcliff, 1994).

Informants in the three districts that passed their levies reported that the high-profile presidential election of November 2008 likely worked to their advantage. An informant from District A (a Republican leaning district) noted the importance of the 2008 Presidential campaign featuring Obama and McCain, noting that the higher democratic turnout was “one of those quirks in the district that helped to get this thing passed—those that were on the fringe, the students, and the folks that don’t vote all the time. I do think it helped with the vote.”

An informant from District B (whose levy was defeated at the polls) stated, “We hoped and planned on higher turnout helping to win. Such was not the case.” When asked about the timing of her district’s levy, an informant from District C simply stated, “We wanted to do this then because of the presidential election.” The Superintendent from District E stated:
We talked about the timing of our campaign in November ‘07. Should we go out in March ‘08? I proposed going out in November of ‘08 at that time. I did not know who the candidates were going to be on either side . . . but I thought the presidential election gave us our best shot.

The community campaign chairman from District E stated,
We actually connected to the back of the Obama headquarters here in . . . They did not use the whole place, so we put our levy headquarters there. So we had literature drops done from there. That is where people picked up the literature. We had a few meetings there and things of that nature.

Only informants from District D reported that the timing would be detrimental to their likelihood of winning. The Superintendent from District D stated:
When we got to the new money which was in November, I knew we would get killed because you have a big presidential election. You are going to have the large turnout. You have biblical proportions of turnout, but we still had to do it. We had to be out there.

The superintendent of this rural, predominantly white school district presumed that voters would not only come out in droves for the McCain–Palin ticket, but that this energized constituency would also vote down new taxes—which they did. The Superintendent would go on to voice his frustration, stating that, “The farmers felt like ‘you are hurting us because you are going for property.’ I don’t think they understand income tax hurts you too. I don’t have time to educate them.” Informants across the districts consistently voiced that voters were concerned about their federal, state, and local tax burdens.

The dire state of the economy in Ohio (and the nation as a whole) exacerbated public concern over additional tax levies in all the sampled districts. Consistent across all informants was the impact of the recession, foreclosures, and job losses, which weighed heavily in the minds of stakeholders, but district finances warranted pursuing the levies. In District B, informants suggested that the amount requested was too much in the face of the recession, paired with unclear consequences and a lack of urgency. An informant from District E commented on the outcome of the levy and the economic conditions at the time, stating,
We were proud of ourselves! Regardless of how [levy passage] happened, it happened. No one thought it would in this district. This district is a poverty-based district. There is a lot of unemployment; a lot of foreclosures here. We were very blessed that the win happened. But it did not happen by accident entirely. We ran an effective campaign so we believe we did put forth the effort and effort that was good.

Our informants across the case study districts were surprisingly consistent in their identification of the four macropolitical conditions that had an impact on campaign planning and implementation. Informants (employees of the districts) acknowledged the state laws governing the fine line that they must walk in pursuing and advocating for their district’s levy. Informants resignedly discussed the in and outs of school funding in Ohio and the inevitability of another levy campaign at some point in their future—that it is not if, but when they are on the ballot the next time. Informants from four of the five districts strategically selected the November 2008 election period in the hopes that high-profile election would increase their likelihood of passage. Informants from District D took their chances in November 2008, but were cynical about their chances of victory. No informants from any of the districts saw the state and local economies—important political issues of the time—as aiding their efforts. Informants also discussed the strategizing that went into these campaigns, but as will be shown, community involvement and strategies varied from district to district based on micropolitical conditions—real and perceived.

sec.title: Micropolitics
sec.p: As these informants have indicated, there were inherent macropolitical challenges that had to be faced. For that matter, there were also micropolitical challenges—local conditions and contexts. Stakeholders had to navigate these local conditions, contexts, and processes through campaign planning and implementation with the hope that Election Day would be one of celebration and not hand-wringing.

sec.title: Local conditions
sec.p: Informants across all districts were consistent in reporting internal debates over when (and if) to place the levy on the ballot, what type to place on the ballot, and the millage to pursue. But once the decision was made, the boards and superintendents were unanimous in their decision to move forward, presenting a united front to the public (see Table 2). As an administrator from District A explained, “There was a lot of hammering behind the scenes about how much, but the board decision was unanimous and it is very important to have that—to have the unanimous vote going in.”

However, less unanimous among the sampled districts was who would assume the chair of the levy campaign committees. Four districts (A, B, C, D) reported difficulties in filling the campaign committee chair position. Only informants from the urban district (E) reported not having this issue. Informants in three districts (A, B, D) reported that the lack of leadership was due to the broader economic conditions and not wanting to spend time on what they assumed would be a tough sell to the community members. However, the superintendent of rural District D offered another reason for a lack of volunteers to chair the local campaign. The superintendent stated, “We all know you want external parents to lead. These people will not lead it in [— School District] because of political reasons. We tried to get people to step up.” The superintendent suggested no one in the community wanted to espouse an increase in property taxes in this largely rural district dominated by large landholding farmers. School board members were reticent to chair, given their position as elected officials; implying that advocacy for and running a campaign could potentially affect their own election outcomes.

Two districts (A and C) reported local controversies leading up to the November campaign, raising concerns that “no voters” would be energized. Interestingly, both these districts (A and C) were able to overcome these issues and win support for their levies by publicly addressing them rather than hoping the issues would just go away. Informants in District A reported three divisive issues. As one informant explained,
We tore down a historical building over the summer that was 5-6 years in the making. It was a question of what to do with it—to sell it or not . . . It was a lot of emotion. People felt strongly about it. The historical society put out a full page ad. We had people criticizing our plan. The other thing was that we had terminated a long-time principal. He was charged with a felony. So that happened right at the start of the school year. The other issue was contract negotiations.

Although District A informants did not describe the collective bargaining process as any more or less adversarial than those of the recent past, it was reported as yet another distraction that needed to be addressed, taking up valuable time from campaign planning. There was also the potential for bad press if the negotiations were protracted. With regards to the collective bargaining and building demolition, one district-level informant explained,
Contracts were settled in June. July is when we had the closing ceremony for the building. We invited everybody in. We had them bring in photographs and stuff like that. I guess it didn’t hurt that we were not announcing the campaign at the same time.

In the end, District A informants consistently reported that addressing these issues publicly and head-on was the best way to deal with them in advance of the November campaign. An informant explained,
The building is gone now obviously . . . We thought about putting a structure there, but when we met with the community groups about it, they suggested we leave it open before you start building stuff. So that is what we are going to do.

Another chimed in stating, “We wanted grass growing [on the lot] by September.” In the case of the dismissal of a building principal, the controversy was handled publicly to the extent that it could, given due process related to personnel dismissals.

District C informants reported that controversy over strained union relations, protracted collective bargaining, and strike threats led to difficulties in finding people willing to serve on the district’s levy committee, to chair it, and raised concerns about the levy’s outcome. The strained union relations and strike threats, in turn, led to strained superintendent–board relations.

Coincidentally, it was the two rural districts (C and D) that both reported having recent appointees to the position of superintendent within their district, strained relations with the school board, tight campaign budgets with very little carryover funds, and having poor relations with media venues. As to experience levels, superintendents from both Districts C and D had 10+ and 20+ years of experience, respectively in education but limited experience in the superintendency (1 and 2 years, respectively).

The rural nature of District C was reported to have influenced which media venues were used in their campaign efforts. Informants stated that because of their location, using the region’s large urban paper was not useful. As the superintendent explained,
We wrote letters and used mailings sent through our local paper because for us to advertise in [the large metropolitan paper] is a waste money because not everyone gets it out here. We used radio because we wanted to stay away from TV.

When asked why, District C’s superintendent explained that the district’s relations with local network affiliates soured “Because of what happened with the teachers [union negotiations and the strike threats].” The district treasurer confirmed this, but suggested that negative television coverage of this rural district preceded the negotiations between the district administration and teacher union. The treasurer explained,
Before the teacher situation we had a $500,000 grant that we turned down. Because of the press coverage, people in the district were saying “here we are in financial crisis and the stupid district turned down this money.” The fact of the matter was people in the district had applied for two grants and it was a duplication of grants, but the press does not cover that!

In the case of District D, the new superintendent not only had strained relations with the school board, but he also self-reported strained relations with the local press. District D’s superintendent stated,
I see my role as to keep the machine going, to continue to market and maintain and build relationships with the press—or trying to even though the local press got mad at me because I was sharing with other media. We need to be outside the box here guys. You are a daily paper but you are shrinking. Deal with those politics!
This superintendent, among all five that were interviewed as part of this study, seemed to struggle with stakeholders the most.

sec.title: The “who” and “what” of campaign participation
sec.p: Anderson (1998) states that “there is general agreement that authentic participatory structures should provide participants with broad jurisdiction, policymaking authority (i.e., not limited to an advisory function), equal representation of relevant stakeholders, and training provisions” (p. 590). As was previously shown, district characteristics, local contexts, and controversies shaped the five sampled districts, making them what they were not only in location but also in a specific period of time. What will now be shown is how these local contexts shaped the districts’ levy campaigns, their broad approaches to stakeholder participation, and what stages of the campaign these stakeholders were involved in.

District A and District B provide examples of two contrasting approaches to community engagement. Both are suburban districts that are very similar in nature of demographics and student performance. While it will be shown that they used some of the same strategies (e.g., phone banks, long-term campaign planning, touting positive student achievement/district performance), the districts differed in broad campaign approaches, specifically seeking to more “authentically” engage community members (Anderson, 1998). District A and the Urban District E both chose to run campaigns that sought and used broad support from community members. District A was even able to enlist community members in providing professional marketing and demography/statistical services at no budgetary costs to the district. Districts A and C actively used students in campaign activities.4 Participation of community stakeholders was at all stages of the campaign, including planning, implementation, and debriefing (see Table 3).

caption.p: Campaign Participants: Who Participates and in What Spheres?

fn.label: b.
fn.p: District level administrators in these districts were reported as being limited to building consensus with school board members for a levy campaign and answering questions at public forums.

sec.p: It should be noted that district leadership was not wholly absent from the issue, After all, it was the superintendents, treasurers, and school boards that made the decision to pursue a levy. Because of the nature of school finance in Ohio, district administrators being “political” and “doing PR” are vitally important if levy campaigns are to be successful. However, administrators from Districts A and E chose to be less in front and more in the background. This allowed community campaign committee members the opportunity for leading, planning, and implementing the levy campaign in pursuit of a favorable levy outcome. As the Superintendent of District E put it, “People see principals and teachers as hired guns and community members as legitimate voices, so the more you get them the better.” It is also important to note that even in the districts that heavily engaged community members, there were strategies seeking to minimize the impact of opposition. These were, after all, campaigns that sought a victory for their cause.

As a contrast, District B and D reported running “central office campaigns”—campaigns in which a small number of key school district stakeholders were involved—largely central office administrators. In the case of District B, district-level administrators cited a history of prior successes in the district with such an approach. Only five parents and/or community members were part of the central office campaign in District B. These participants served in the campaign implementation stage only. While a community member was reported as serving as campaign committee chair, informants indicated that administrators at the district and building level did “all the heavy lifting.” The position was honorary and advisory in nature with only nominal participation.

District C’s campaign was an odd mixture of involving parents, community members, and students, but the prolonged contract negotiations, bad press, and high emotions led to deviations from past practices within the district. This included a shorter campaign, a temporary abandonment of particular campaign strategies, and less teacher involvement. With regard to the first, the campaign was planned to be shorter than previous ones in the district. This was to give less time for opponents to mobilize and a time to focus on targeting likely “yes” voters. An informant explained,
This was probably the meanest we ever won only because of the political position we were in—people being confused and emotional . . . There were a lot of mixed emotions in the community. The campaign was in tune to that. There was a portion of the population that was not for us. We did not direct our campaign toward them, but we did toward the ones who would support us.

What resulted was a “quick campaign” that was long in the planning. The district’s long-serving treasurer described the planning as “the most strategic” [she] had ever seen,” with campaign planning reported to have begun in the spring of the previous academic year. The district chose to use select parents and students, making this a campaign that, albeit in a limited fashion, engaged the community. “Typical” campaign tactics were shelved in District C to adapt to the specifics of this campaign. As one informant explained, the use of volunteer community members working in phone banks to make calls to constituents was abandoned in this campaign, “because of the controversy . . . Normally, we would do cold calling, but we wanted the right message out there.” Informants in District C also reported that teachers would typically have been a driving force as leading advocates for levy passage, but in this campaign, teachers were less active as a result of the strained negotiations. The district’s treasurer stated, “The teachers did not support it, but after negotiations some of them got out. Like I said; if it was not for the negotiations they would have been more involved.”

In this section, we have contrasted two broad approaches to community engagement—the community-led campaign (Districts A and E) and the central office campaign (Districts B and D). District C, a rural district whose levy passed, was harder to categorize, given the micropolitical contexts within which it operated (e.g., strained contract negotiations). We have sought to capture what stakeholder groups participated, how many of each stakeholder group were involved, and in what stages of the campaign (planning, implementation, and debriefing) they were involved. We now turn our attention to the wide variety of campaign strategies that were used and finally, what strategies the three winning districts used in comparison to the two districts that lost their campaigns.

sec.title: Campaign Strategies
sec.p: In answering our third research question—How did successful districts differ in political strategies from districts that were not successful?—there was a wide range of strategies reported (see Table 4). We begin by discussing the strategies that were implemented across the three successful district campaigns or wholly absent in unsuccessful district campaigns (e.g., community campaigns vs. central office campaigns)—what we call contrasting strategies. We then turn our attention to strategies that were, in essence, a “mixed bag”—working in some districts, but not in others. We prioritize these strategies; first examining strategies that were reported across all sampled district regardless of outcome at the polls and providing a nuanced look at what might explain why a mixed-bag strategy yielded the desired outcome in one district and not another.

caption.p: Strategies Implemented by the Sampled Districts

tr.td: School board member served as chair/co-chair
Preemptive budget cutting prior to levy
Online social networking use/target youth vote
Use of board of elections/precinct data
