sec.p: As was alluded to in the previous discussions, the biggest difference between districts that had levies approved and those that did not were the extent to which the campaigns engaged community members. Districts A, C, and E ran community campaigns that, to varying degrees, sought the input and energies of community stakeholders, including students. District B and D, in contrast, ran central office campaigns that, at best, engaged the various stakeholder groups in limited ways.

Our analysis reinforces Anderson’s (1998) contention that the provision of adequate training is a condition and process for authentic community participation. In campaign planning, informants from successful campaigns discussed the importance of adequate message training. The community campaign chairperson from District E stated,
When we talked to voters we kept the message simple and clear. The message training was such people could repeat it in their sleep. I think that was very helpful. The community members who were making the phone calls were true believers.

In unsuccessful districts, there was a message. At its most elemental, it was to support the levy and thus support schools. For example, rural District D’s message was reported as “focus[ing] on being frugal, how cheap the levy was and how important it will be to maintain the programs including the holy trinity—football, band and FFA [Future Farmers of America].” However, informants from unsuccessful districts reported post hoc that adequate message training was absent or woefully inadequate. As one District D informant stated, “Dealing with people who are not trained trying to train other people. It did not go perfect.”

Message training (or message coaching, as one district called it) was consistently described as scheduling time in which volunteers were explained the basics of the levy on the ballot, why the time was right to go on the ballot, the great things that students and teachers were doing, what sacrifices/cuts have already been made, and a list of potential (or specific) cuts that would be made if the levy does not pass. Trainers—a principal, teacher, or community member who had previous experience with levy campaigns—would explain what to expect and typical responses from citizens when calling or doing door-to-door visits. Training sought to ensure a consistent message and how to deal with negative voters. In campaign planning, informants from successful campaigns discussed the importance of adequate message training. In the case of District A, it also included how to collect rudimentary campaign data. During the course of calling and canvassing, adamant “no” voters and “yes” voters were identified. For the former, any further mailings were stopped to save money. For the latter, community members were identified as being supportive, thus receiving a reminder call on Election Day, reminding them to vote.

While four of the five districts (A, B, C, D) reported difficulties in filling the campaign committee chair position, eventually leaders would step up. However, there were differences in who these leaders would be and the eventual levy outcomes. Districts who won at the polls reported having a community member at least co-chair the campaign. District A had a school board member and a parent from the community serve as co-chairs. District C had a parent in the community serve as a chairperson, but was heavily assisted by a district-level support staff member. District E, like District A, had a school board member and a community member serve as co-chairs. District B had a community member serve, but the position was described in terms of an honorary appointment with nominal participation. An informant indicated that all the campaign’s “heavy lifting” was done by administration and central office staff. Likewise, District D used district-level membership. District D’s superintendent, among the five superintendents that we interviewed, rationalized the lack of leadership among community members as to why he and other district-level administrators ran a central office campaign. At times, the superintendent seemed to express a disdain for the school board and for the community that employs him. For example, District D’s superintendent at one point stated, “You know what? People [in the community] are going to find a reason to vote no. People will find a reason not to take the lead too.”

The three districts with winning campaigns also shared another strategy that the two districts with losing campaigns did not—informational websites. Websites funded by community campaign committees and citizen’s donations could be partisan in nature. For example, District A had a website external to the school district that could advocate for a yes vote. District E’s superintendent indicated that his district’s approach was to use the existing website, but provide nonpartisan information. He stated, “We put facts on the school website. We have to be careful [alluding to state law].” Similarly, informants from successful districts used school/central office marquees to publicly advertise nonpartisan “get out the vote” reminders in an effort to remind parents, teachers, and voting age students to vote, but not to vote a particular way.

Informants across the districts discussed the role of creating a sense of urgency in message training (or lack thereof). The two suburban districts (A and B) provide evidence of this dichotomy. District A created a sense of urgency in their community. In advance of the campaign, preemptive cuts to the budget were made. Furthermore, a long list of potential and additional cuts was announced. Informants from District A rationalized this strategy. Announcing specific cuts would only energize voters that had a stake in those programs. This avoided what Anderson (1998) has called participation as collusion, by presenting a wide range of possible cuts that affected as wide a range of stakeholders as possible.

District B’s administratively led, low-key campaign targeted “yes” voters with a positive message (e.g., student performance, sport, and extracurricular offerings) in the hopes of avoiding the mobilization of any opposition. A teacher from District B contrasted the November 2008 campaign with that of the (eventually successful) campaign that followed it. He stated,
In the November [2008] campaign, we accentuated the positives rather than talk about doom and gloom and what we might lose if this thing didn’t pass. Well that did not work, so the next campaign was the total opposite. The district made substantial cuts and threatened more.

For District B, the urgency only emerged when the November 2008 levy failed. The district had no option but to pursue another levy—a levy that would eventually pass after making preemptive cuts and a long, well-publicized list of additional and potential cuts. Their following campaign would actually model that of District A, involving community members in planning and implementation of the next campaign.

Urgency in the case of District E—the large urban district— also centered on the threat of additional cuts to programming, specifically buses and after-school programming. Like District A, preemptive cuts were already made and publicized followed by a list of more potential cuts. Targeting their message to specific organizations worked for District E. For example, a meeting with sports boosters would include emphasis placed on sports as being on a list of potential cuts. Among African American voters and community organizations, the message was get out the vote and prevent cuts to valuable programs and services. Among Caucasian voters, it was what might result if there were cuts to these programs. The superintendent explained,
We made it clear that we were going to cut out sports and extracurricular activities and that we would curtail busing—all the nasty things you do. But they are real things too . . . We need extracurricular activities for after school. One of the messages was “Do you want kids hanging around in your back yard?” We hate to say it, but it’s true. Kids need things to do after school. If not, they will be in the neighborhoods.
The message was made clear. A “no vote” could very well lead to even higher crime rates.

Anderson (1998) is careful to make a distinction between participation as consumerism and participation as citizenship (p. 584). Only informants from the urban district (District E) discussed the impact that Ohio Edchoice had on district enrollment and finances. Ohio Edchoice provides a limited number of state-funded scholarships to students who attend low-performing public school buildings. The scholarships may be used to attend private schools and community (charter) schools that meet requirements for program participation (ODE, 2010). As the treasurer explained, “We talked about the effect of charter schools and Edchoice vouchers on the district . . . Not in a whiny sort of way; just as a matter of fact. We wanted to educate the community.” Another informant explained,
We have lost a lot to vouchers and charter schools—around 10 million dollars accumulated over time . . . These vouchers; we just can’t make it up. We didn’t lose all the 10 million dollars because we don’t have to teach those kids. It is a lagging indicator I guess . . . so the net loss in effect was about 6.5 million to Edchoice vouchers and charter school. So that is why we needed more from people.

Districts A and E also had structured campaign committee and subcommittee systems that increased the likelihood of follow-through on campaign activities. District A, in particular, had a structured door-to-door campaign, in which parents, community members, and students canvassed the entire district. Similar structure and discipline ran across all subcommittees and their accepted tasks. Campaign committees from District A (suburban) and District E (urban) reported brainstorming and identifying public venues in which they could get their message out. This included local events and festivals. District A’s campaign committee used these highly public and well-trafficked events to give out t-shirts and yard signs in exchange for “suggested donation amounts.” The sales of these items were a way to not only get out the vote but to also add to the campaign committee’s financial resources.

Anderson (1998) has noted the importance of engaging all relevant stakeholders for community engagement to be “authentic.” District A, in particular, was effective in enlisting the support of community members through the donation of in-kind services, including statistical analysis of Board of Elections data and marketing/printing/mailing services. District A also engaged students in their cause to a greater extent than any other of the sampled districts, primarily in the campaign implementation stage. Students also took limited roles in campaign planning, especially in the realm of Internet social networking (e.g., Facebook)—a venue in which adult stakeholders had either little or no knowledge about. It was in this capacity that District A high school students planned and implemented strategies for energizing voting-age students (current and college-going alumni). These were demographics that campaign committee members realized would be more likely to vote for Obama and for the levy.

Among the sampled districts, District A used the broadest array of strategies in pursuit of levy passage. Other successful districts had strategies that were used only in single districts. For example, District C (rural) used resources for local newspaper advertising. District E’s levy campaign had the resources for a campaign consultant and was successful in gaining the support of local politicians. As the Superintendent put it:
I really can’t underestimate what the mayor and city council did. It is risky business supporting a levy when you’re a mayor or a city council member. We have a very good working relationship—great respect and admiration. It has been good for us. It has not always been that way.

We now turn our attention to the “mixed bag” strategies that were implemented by both successful and unsuccessful districts. We first look at the strategies that were used by all the sampled districts regardless of voter outcomes. These were the use of campaign signs, community informational sessions, nonpartisan voting reminders, and Board of Elections/precinct data. We will start with what is one of the most commonly used levy campaign strategy for getting out the vote—campaign signs. In a recent study (Johnson & Ingle, 2009), 73% of responding superintendents reported the use of signage in their levy campaigns. Because of the frequency of levies in Ohio, informants reported keeping unused signs and collecting signs after the campaign was over. These would be stored for what would inevitably be the next campaign. The frequency of campaigns and the desire to make the most of limited resources led to designs that were generic in nature, not specifying what levy or issue number. Signs would simply read something like “Support — Schools.” There was an exception though. In District C, informants reported using “50 dollars for tape to cover [the old election day dates on] old signs.” Informants wondered jokingly if the recycled signs with duct tape on them helped not only in saving money but also in illustrating publicly how tight the budget was (and remains).

Informational sessions were hosted in a variety of public locations (e.g., schools, public library, YMCA) and private residences. As mentioned previously, §9.03 of the Ohio Revised Code allows districts to expend public funds to communicate information, but not to support or oppose the passage of a levy or bond issue. In districts that engaged community members on their levy campaign committees, community members took the partisan “vote yes!” message to those in attendance while district administrators answered questions that were raised. If community members did not take active roles in the campaigns or campaign committee, superintendents and treasurers simply stated that the school board had placed a levy on the ballot and that they would host a public forum to take questions.

Of all the districts, Districts A and E—both successful in their campaigns—used informational sessions most extensively. District A, in particular, kept precise records of all community informational sessions, their locations, who would moderate, and the school board member or district administrator that was present to take questions. In total, District A hosted a total of 21 community informational speakers. Campaign committee members also tracked attendance, which ranged from 5 to 30 attendees. Like District A, informants in District E indicated that campaign committee members typically led the events, with a board member or district administrator in attendance to answer questions. In Districts A and E, central office administrators took low-key roles in planning and implementing the campaigns, leaving the “nuts and bolts” of the campaign to community members. Beyond initial consulting with the school board about the need to proceed with a levy campaign, district-level administrators attended community forums, answered questions, and advised on an as needed basis.

In the case of Districts B, C, and D, informational sessions, “town halls,” and questions and answer sessions were held, but tended to be led by the Superintendent. A school-level administrator from District B reported, “Our Superintendent took part in coffee clutches. We went to homes and churches.” A District C informant stated that during the course of the short campaign, “We had public forums and Q & A during every board meeting.” Likewise, District D’s superintendent reported,
We had town hall meetings. We talked about the downsizing. We had three different town hall meetings. The first one we had focus groups because we did not want a mob. So focus groups met. At least we did not have a mob of people standing in the back yelling. We diffused that. It ticked them off.

Malen (1994) has noted that the suppression of conflict and exclusion of interests result from a number of factors, including administrators’ capacity to control the agenda. This statement from the Superintendent of District D suggests what Meyer and Rowan (1977) called legitimating rituals, such that on their face, these events provide a venue for community engagement, but the format and input are controlled by district administration. Their efficacy as an opportunity for authentic community participation is questionable. What is less questionable was the outcome—a failed levy in this district.

Informants from all five districts reported the use of nonpartisan “get out the vote” reminders. These were done in a variety of ways, including the use of newsletters, school/central office marquees, e-mail list serves, and school/central office websites. Again, §9.03 of the Ohio Revised Code limited districts to using these media as a means of reminding parents, teachers, and voting-age students to vote, but not to vote a particular way. Their hope was that these stakeholders would be more likely to vote yes. This was not the case for websites funded by community campaign committees and citizen’s donations, which were partisan in nature.

Informants from all five districts also reported the use of Board of Elections/precinct data in campaign strategizing. However, some districts were more strategic in their use of the data, analyzing how and which precincts voted on previous levy issues. Anderson (1998) identified the use of newsletters and other one-way forms of communication as “participation as public relations” (p. 576). Three districts (A, B, and E) reported the use of targeting mailings to likely “yes voters,” but District E opted to use both targeted mailings and “blanket newsletters” that went out to all households in the district. Of all the sampled districts, suburban District A undertook the most extensive targeting, differentiating mailings based on parental status and age. Elderly voters and those who did not have children in schools received mailings with different messages (quality schools aid in keeping property values high, remaining a “destination district,” and keeping the community’s high quality of life). Parents in the district received these messages too, but the emphasis was on providing quality education and services to their children at current levels without any further cuts. The superintendent of District D also reported a campaign that sought to target potential “yes” voters, rationalizing that:
I don’t want to waste my time going after all the voters. I want to go after the obvious “yes” voters—parents and employees. Spend your time on those groups and parents who are not registered. We identified 1,300 households of parents—1,300 times 2. I should have had 2600 votes . . . Why waste your time on 8,000 people who are not going to show up? I hope they don’t show up!

In the end, this did not work for District D, but this strategy was likely blunted by a wide array of factors, including strained relations between the board and superintendent, the superintendent and press, and the superintendent and the public.

The two suburban districts (A and B) both reported the use of Board of Elections data for targeting absentee voters, but with differing election outcomes. Absentee voting was reported to be in higher numbers because of the presidential election. An informant from District B stated, “We really spent time with the absentee voters. When they registered at the board of elections, we sent something out to them within 2 days of when they registered.” A lesson learned by District A informants was to begin even earlier. A campaign committee member stated,
It would have been nice if we could have started earlier [with absentee voters] and that was something that we were concerned about. In an ideal situation you should shift to accommodate that. I think in future elections we will have to back up the time line.

The superintendent added, “We ran into a handful of people who were like, ‘I wish I would have known. I already voted.’ We heard enough of that kind of thing where that might be a factor in the future.”

Also varying from district to district and yielding mixed results was the amount time spent in campaign planning and implementation. Informants from four of the five districts reported extended campaign planning (3 months or more). Campaign length varied, with Districts A, D, and E reporting campaigns lasting longer than 6 weeks. District B reported a 5- to 6-week campaign. Interestingly, District C reported a purposefully and strategically holding a campaign lasting only 3 to 4 weeks, which also yielded a victory at the polls for its levy.

We conclude our discussion with the remaining “mixed bag” marketing strategies reported by districts (successful or not). All were efforts to market the campaign and encourage constituents to vote yes on the levy. These included touting student academic achievement, the use of phone banks, and the use of media outlets. Among the five districts, the two suburban districts could use a record of strong academic achievement and resulting “excellent with distinction” ratings as part of their message to the voters. Part of their messages was that with levy passage, they could continue this success. Without levy passage, this record of success could be jeopardized.

Three districts (A, B, and E) used “phone banks” to call voters in the district and ask for their support of the levy by a yes vote. District C sought a shortened campaign that eschewed the blanket calling of voters present in previous campaigns. This strategy was viewed as one that would likely energize no voters, given the simmering controversies within the district. The informants from District C suggested that phone banks could potentially do more harm than good.

Three districts—suburban District A, and the two rural districts (C and D)—drew on community members willing to write letters to the editor, advocating that the community at large vote in favor of the levy. The superintendents and treasurers of the two rural districts reported taking part in local radio call in shows to answer questions from the community. Only two districts reported using TV advertising. District E informants reported strong public support from the union, which at the state level is generally supportive of school budget referenda. The campaign chair from District E stated,
The OEA [Ohio Education Association] developed an advertisement spot. It was sort of a generic spot and they would insert the community name and the issue number. It was paid for by the OEA. The cable channels ran them on the local channels.

TV advertising was also a strategy used by suburban District B. This entailed using a student-produced video, touting positive aspects of the district, its students and teachers with the hopes that a positive message would encourage a yes vote while remaining within state law. However, the outcomes for these two districts would be mixed—a passed levy for urban District E and a failed levy in suburban District B.

sec.title: Summary of Findings
sec.p: This study sought to understand how the macropolitical (state and national) contexts shaped stakeholders’ decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation. It also sought to understand how the micropolitical (within district) contexts shaped stakeholder decision making in terms of campaign strategizing and participation. Last, this study asked if successful districts differed in their use political strategies from districts that were not successful. Here, we summarize our findings to these three questions, respectively.

As to the macropolitical contexts, we identified four macropolitical themes consistent across all sampled districts—state campaign policies, state education finance policy, the high profile nature of the Presidential election, and the state of the economy. While the macropolitical themes cut across all five sampled districts, the micropolitical contexts were a mixture of similarities and contrasts. Mawhinney (1999) has noted the emphasis on conflict rather than consensus in micropolitical studies. Informants in all districts reported strategies to minimize and suppress conflict with opponents of tax increases. Even districts that more heavily engaged their communities had strategies for targeting yes voters that would hopefully improve the likelihood of winning at the polls while minimizing the impact of no voters. There were efforts to suppress conflict and competing interests, such as District D’s “town halls”—the format of which suppressed angry citizen voices (and only emboldened them further).

Despite a small sample, districts varied greatly in strategies used and community involvement. Districts that heavily engaged community members across the multiple stakeholder groups (including students) and created a sense of urgency yielded greater success at the polls than “central office campaigns.” Districts with co-chairs that included community members with active rather than passive participation fared better than the two districts with failed levies who, in contrast, had administrators chairing or a community chair that was only there in name, but not substance. Adequate message training for campaign participants was also key to success. Its reported absence in the two failed campaigns suggests its importance.

Looking across the five districts and the strategies they implemented (see Table 4), one will notice some strategies in common across sampled districts and some that were unique to just one. A simple quantification of strategies suggests that more seemed to matter for the successful districts (A and E), who implemented more than Districts B and D that had failed campaigns. However, District C strategically pursued a shorter campaign that was preceded by months of planning that took into consideration the local conditions and controversies, adjusting accordingly. Their typical strategies used in previous campaigns were strategically unused this time, yielding a win at the polls.

In summary, our study offers important insight into the complexities of the environments and strategies used in levy campaigns. Each campaign is truly a case study of the micropolitics within which the district stakeholders must live and operate. Macropolitical factors in the state of Ohio (particularly its school-funding approach) have forced educators to think and act politically in terms of levy campaigns. One could argue that the macropolitical environment is overemphasizing the political at the expense of what educators are paid to provide and facilitate—teaching and learning.

sec.title: Implications for Practitioners
sec.p: Timing levy campaigns with presidential elections has been suggested as increasing the likelihood of success (Fleeter, 2007). While voter turnout is typically higher in U. S. presidential elections than in state, midterm, and local elections, the conventional wisdom that education issues benefit from high voter turnout may be misguided, given the mixed results from the political science field (e.g., DeNardo, 1980; Nagel & McNulty, 1996; Osborn et al., 2010; Radcliff, 1994). Our data suggest that timing will mean nothing if adequate consideration is not given to the macro- and micropolitical realities on the ground.

Our study also suggests that community volunteers—especially student volunteers—can be a valuable resource that is often underused. The value of community volunteers (including students) is for two primary reasons. One has been evidenced in cost analysis studies (Ingle, Petroff, & Johnson, 2011; Brent, 2000). Ingle, Petroff, and Johnson (2011) found that community volunteers—especially student volunteers—can be a valuable resource in that they incur lower costs than central office campaigns whose administrative salaries drive up opportunity costs. Economically, student volunteerism (and volunteerism in general) reflects very little accounting costs beyond training and recognition (e.g., Ingle, Petroff, & Johnson, 2011; Brent, 20005). But as an informant from District E cogently explained, community members are more likely to be perceived as “legitimate voices” that can energize public support for levy campaigns.

Returning to student volunteerism, this study provided some evidence that students have valuable knowledge and skill sets (e.g., social networking) that added value to one district’s campaign efforts. Their knowledge and skill sets were reported by informants in this study and by others (e.g., Hollander & Longo, 2008) as assisting to energize voters, particularly among their demographic, who tended to vote Democratic in the November 2008 Presidential campaign (Caswell, 2009). Their vote also trended in favor of the levy in their districts.6

District personnel and/or campaign committee members should plan for effective volunteer training and recognition when planning a district’s campaign. As to the first, emphasis should be on maximizing volunteer utility by adequately preparing volunteers in message training. This entails sending a consistent message that is thoughtfully formulated for delivery in activities, such as door-to-door campaigns, community festivals, and/or town hall meetings. Districts may also consider targeting messages to specific stakeholder groups within their district, presenting their communities with extensive lists of services, programs (e.g., extracurricular), and positions that might be cut if the levy were to fail. This is opposite of listing specific cuts, which may not pique the interest and concern of all voters. Such specificity may only energize subpopulations within the district that have vested interests in those programs.

The second is recognition programs, which as will be shown below, is related to message training. Given the propensity of Ohio districts to be on the ballot with regularity, recognition programs are a means by which community volunteers with prior levy campaign experience can be encouraged to return for future campaigns. Stakeholders who have prior experience in levy campaigns can be a valuable resource in training new volunteers, providing valuable insight into what to expect when the new recruits canvas neighborhoods. Their experience can add value to future campaign efforts. Volunteer recognition can thus be as an investment in the district’s future campaign efforts.

This study provides a glimpse into the windows of five districts, the macro/micropolitical environments in which districts operate and the efforts that districts and individuals put forth in pursuit of additional or status quo funding for schools. Research (Ingle, Petroff, & Johnson, 2011; Ingle, Johnson, & Petroff, 2011) has estimated the total cost of campaigns in districts. Given all these efforts on individual campaigns, one wonders whether all these efforts and resources could be redirected into a statewide push for broader school finance reform that allows for automatic inflationary increases in local property taxes? In sum, they have. Organizations such as the Ohio School Boards Association have historically advocated for school finance reform, including the call for legislation that “provides for inflationary growth to ensure an adequate and equitable funding system for Ohio’s public schools . . . [and] funding growth adequate to address revenue needs without requiring voter approval of new tax levies” (Ohio School Boards Association, 2011). Likewise, the Ohio Education Association has also historically challenged state lawmakers to change how schools are funded in Ohio (e.g., Ohio Education Association, 2011a) while also working to defeat Governor Kasich’s Issue 2—a referenda on legislation, which sought, among other things, to change how teachers are paid, limit public sector collective bargaining rights, and increase public employees’ retirement contributions (Ohio Education Association, 2011b). We recommend that school/district personnel, school boards, and Ohio voters continue to advocate for such changes and renew their advocacy for statewide changes to school finance in Ohio and challenge policymakers to address an issue that they have thus far avoided—the unconstitutionality of Ohio school-funding approach.7 We offer some suggestions to policymakers below.

sec.title: Implications for Policy Makers
sec.p: While there are no quick fixes in education funding, policy makers in Ohio must take steps to address problems in Ohio’s approach to funding education. There are some potential policy responses that policy makers could consider. The provisions of Ohio H.B. 920, which severely limit the growth of school district revenues as property values rise, became part of the Ohio constitution through voter referendum in 1980. One way to mollify the effects of H.B. 920 would be through a constitutional amendment allowing for tax revenue growth for school districts. This change would benefit local governments in Ohio, but especially school districts, reducing the number and frequency of ballot issues. Unfortunately, given the current political climate in Ohio, any such referendum would have difficulty getting on the ballot, let alone prevailing in a statewide referendum.

Property tax circuit breakers could provide tax relief to low-income and elderly residents whose taxes exceed a given percentage of income (Allen & Woodberry, 2006). Along the same lines, property tax deferral programs are designed to allow eligible homeowners the option of delaying the payment of property taxes until the home is sold or the owner’s estate is settled and are typically targeted to the elderly and the disabled (Haveman & Sexton, 2008).

In spite of a state Supreme Court ruling that Ohio’s school-funding formula is overly reliant on the use of local property taxes, it seems unlikely that Ohio is poised to move away from property taxes to any great degree in the near future. Besides, there are those who argue that voting on local property taxes keep citizens connected to their local schools—that this is a means of community engagement and democracy in action. Governor Strickland’s efforts to increase the state’s share of the funding formula was based on a foundation amount that many believed was too low to begin with and was to be phased in over a 10-year period (Phillis, 2009). With the election of Republican governor, John Kasich, and a Republican-controlled legislature, there is less state funding earmarked for local districts in the biennial budget. The burden will remain on local taxpayers to make up the difference. The need for districts to frequently be on the ballot will likely not go away any time soon. Given the expanded role over time of the federal government in public education (see McDonnell, 2005), one wonders whether we are seeing a shift in public opinion in regards to funding of public education, such that local communities are more supportive of federal funding of education rather than continuing to foot the lion’s share of tax revenue.

sec.title: Implications for Future Research
sec.p: As mentioned previously, an obvious limitation of this five-district case study is its lack of generalizability. A remedy to this limitation is to quantitatively examine the relationship between implemented campaign strategies and expenditures on levy outcomes over time. The biggest challenge would be gaining access to knowledgeable individuals in districts who can report campaign strategies and specific expenditures accurately. Given the sheer number of districts on the ballot in any given year in Ohio, this is no small task. A recent study (Johnson & Ingle, 2009) surveyed superintendents on the use of campaign strategies and testing their relationship with a dichotomous outcome, but the study was limited in its generalizability to one point in time (November 2007). Ideally, superintendents and/or campaign committee chairs would be surveyed whenever there is a levy on the ballot (in Ohio, there are four periods of time in a year). Over time, longitudinal data combining district variables and survey responses could be gathered to test the efficacy of these strategies and expenditures. However, there is a practical consideration that currently serves as a hindrance to this. Superintendents already suffering from “levy fatigue” (Johnson & Ingle, 2009) would likely suffer from survey fatigue as well.

Under Ohio’s accountability system, districts are rated using multiple measures, including performance on state indicators, a performance index score, Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP), and value-added data. The performance index and value-added results recognize the achievement levels of students as well as progress over time. School and districts are designated as “Excellent with Distinction,” “Excellent,” “Effective,” “Continuous Improvement,” “Academic Watch,” or “Academic Emergency.” The “Excellent with Distinction” designation was new to the 2007-2008 Local Report Card. This designation is earned when a school or district has been designated “Excellent” and exceeds value-added goals for 2 consecutive years.

These were create a clear vision for the district’s future; justify the need; create a sense of urgency; establish an ongoing school–community relations program; use all data available; survey constituents; consider the amount requested; consider the timing and length of the campaign; ensure board unity; involve community leaders, staff and media; educate district staff and students; analyze previous elections; establish a diverse campaign committee; focus on “Yes” voters; disseminate information; focus on the benefits; use experts; keep a low administration profile; use technology; avoid controversy; and debrief regardless of the results.
For in-depth discussions of Ohio’s education funding system, see Alexander and Alexander (2009), Hunter (2000), and Maxwell and Sweetland (2008).

It should be noted that District B also used students but in a passive and limited basis. Specifically, students from a media class put together an informational commercial for local cable broadcasting. The video highlighted positive things that the district, educators, and students had done (or were doing). This activity was part of a class assignment and per Ohio Revised Code, could not advocate specifically for a “Yes” vote.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: William Kyle Ingle is an assistant professor in the School of Educational Foundations, Leadership, and Policy at Bowling Green State University. His research focuses on the politics of education and human resource functions in education.

Paul Andrew Johnson is an associate professor in the School of Educational Foundations, Leadership, and Policy at Bowling Green State University. His research focuses on board of education–superintendent relations and community engagement.

Ruth Ann Petroff is a doctoral candidate in the School of Educational Foundations, Leadership, and Policy and Fahle Scholar (2009-2010) at Bowling Green State University. Her research focuses on the relationship between leadership attributes and effectiveness across private, public, and non-profit sectors.
